Author: Malti#3948
Content: is this the cc channel for the fiat gateway to the dex?

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: No. The gateways CC is for making a gateway from external chains like (BTC,KMD,LTC...) to a Komodo asset chain. You can deposit 1 BTC on Bitcoin blockchain, and get 1 BTCT token on asset chain.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Hi,
I'm looking into how to tokenize physical objects for trading with the goal of creating a testcase demo.  I'm stepping quite far out of my depth and would appreciate any help with the noob questions I'll have.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Here's the first,
Fungible or non-fungible?  In the (example) case where I wanted to tokenize my house.

Author: Alright#0419
Content: @CrisF do you have two fungible houses? :troll:

Author: Alright#0419
Content: just google "fungible" if you don't know what it means

Author: Alright#0419
Content: in the case of a house, if it's split over multiple tokens somehow, those tokens are "fungible" with each other

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if it's a single token, it's "non-fungible" as there is no other

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Yeah, I googled it.  
So it is the total asset that is non-fungible.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: I was thinking of the case that I split the house into many tokens, like shares in the house.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: (There's going to be really noob questions like these!)

Author: Alright#0419
Content: if there are 5 tokens to that represent 1/5 of a house each, those 5 tokens are fungible with each other

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: That's what I was thinking.  So I'm not sure whether to chose fungible or non-fungible when creating the token.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: I would like the individual tokens to be fungible with each other.

Author: johnwhitestar#1227
Content: I'd like to ask, the gateways are based on multisig, right?

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: https://developers.komodoplatform.com/basic-docs/antara/antara-api/gateways.html#gatewaysbind

Author: johnwhitestar#1227
Content: @smk762 -  dracocanis ominator Thank you for the documentation. I've already read it, and what I understood is that the gateways are based on multisig, i.e. that one can withdraw from a gateway only if the owner/owners of the gateway let him to. Have I understood right?

Author: smk762 -  dracocanis ominator#7640
Content: Correct, though you can set one up and be ins owner, and the validation process is handled by an oraclefeed automatically (which must be kept running) for both deposits and withdrawls. It can be tricky to get your head around, but there is a walkthrough on the dev docs site.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: @johnwhitestar Yes, gateway can be multisig but it also can be single signature. The point with multisig is to make the deposit and withdraw as decentralized as possible. The idea for some gateways that will be ran on KMD asset chains is that notary nodes (which are trusted as they do the dPoW) also run oraclefeed which is responsible for posting external chain block data and responsible for withdraws. For example it will be gateway with 7of15 signatures necessary for withdraw or even more.

Author: Mihailo#5902
Content: Single signature gateways is basically centralized as you are puting trust in one point that can become corrupted, and you are throwing away all the point of blockchain. But probably there will be cases for single sig gateways.

Author: johnwhitestar#1227
Content: @Mihailo I'm specifically interested in decentralized solution. I'm thinking to create "smart tokens" based on KMD for a currency I'm quite involved in. So that currency would acquire off-chain KMD CC functionality. For that reason I'd need a gateway from and into KMD for that currency. But of course if it's just me who guaranties that gateway it's doesn't look out serious. Can I use KMD notaries for that purpose then, right? So there are automated 15 signatures to guaranty withdrawals from the gateway, am I understanding it right?
